author: xda-developers.com
title: I might switch to Windows if Apple keeps making macOS more annoying for power users
text:
Menu
Sign in now Close News & Deals Submenu News Deals Reviews Submenu Laptops CPUs Graphics cards SSDs Product Awards Best Guides Submenu Best Laptops Best Chromebooks Best CPUs Best graphics cards Tutorials Submenu Windows macOS Linux ChromeOS Threads Topics Submenu Acer Apple Dell HP Lenovo Microsoft Razer Sign in Newsletter Trending Copilot+ Snapdragon X Series Windows 11 2024 Update On this day Forums Close I might switch to Windows if Apple keeps making macOS more annoying for power users macOS Sequoia: A new Siri, window snapping, and everything else you need to know By Brady Snyder Published 1 hour ago Thread Your changes have been saved
Email is sent
Email has already been sent
close Please verify your email address.
Send confirmation email close You‚Äôve reached your account maximum for followed topics.
Manage Your List Follow Followed Follow with Notifications Follow Unfollow Share Facebook Flipboard Copy link Link copied to clipboard Sign in to your XDA account
Key Takeaways A new macOS Sequoia behavior will make users grant permission for apps that need screen sharing on a monthly basis. The change covers any app that does screen sharing or recording, but also applies to apps with color pickers and screenshot utilities, potentially adding hassle to the workflows of power users. While this behavior is appearing in the macOS Sequoia developer beta and is not official, this is far from the first macOS change to negatively affect enthusiasts and professionals on the platform. The idea that one desktop operating system, like macOS, Windows, or Linux, can be the absolute best is a false notion. As much as I love using the best Macs for productivity work, I understand two basic factors that influence desktop users above all else. It's not about specs, hardware, user-interface, or even any one specific feature. Instead, the OS that you know how to use and feel familiar with will likely always be preferred, and the type of work you need to do will play a role as well. I've been a macOS user my entire life, and I don't think using Windows 11 will ever feel as natural to me as using macOS Sonoma .
When this reality is brought up, people often criticize those who feel too comfortable with macOS, Linux, or Windows to switch operating systems as being unwilling to learn. I disagree ‚Äî because if something works, it works. As much as I love using my Lenovo Yoga Book 9i as a mobile workstation, macOS works better for my workflow because I've already mastered it.
It works, and until it doesn't, I have no reason to switch to Windows. But lately, as Apple makes macOS more tailored to casual users, and I start needing more from my Macs as a power user, I wonder if our wants and needs are diverging.
Related macOS Sequoia hands-on: Apple finally figured out how to snap windows macOS Sequoia is like macOS Sonoma, but with window snapping built-in.
Apple made a few frustrating changes to macOS over the last few releases that specifically affected power users, professionals, and enthusiasts. Now, the biggest annoyance is set to come with macOS Sequoia, which is set to launch in about a month or less. For me, it represents a tipping of the scales. If Apple keeps making macOS more annoying, I might go all-in on Windows 11.
macOS Sequoia will change how you use your Mac And it's not for the better ‚Äî using color pickers, screenshot tools, and video meetings will be more annoying Close I've been experimenting with the macOS Sequoia developer beta for months now, and there's a lot to like. Finally, Apple has a window management tool comparable to what Windows offers. Apple Intelligence is impressive, even if that's just based on early impressions. And, there's a new screen sharing feature that makes it clearer to see what you're sharing with people and apps.
Unfortunately, everything else related to screen sharing is about to get a lot more difficult. Earlier this month, macOS Sequoia users started to see a new pop-up asking them to grant permission for each app that uses screen sharing on a weekly basis. Many thought this was a bug, initially, but it was later revealed that this was the intended behavior. Understandably, there was public outcry. Can you imagine having to manually give Google Meet or Zoom permission to share your screen once per week? It's the kind of behavior Microsoft was slammed for in the past.
Related I tried 5 new Apple Intelligence features in macOS Sequoia, here‚Äôs how it went The flagship features aren‚Äôt available yet, but I‚Äôm already impressed by the Apple Intelligence beta.
3 In a subsequent beta release, Apple shifted the pop-up interval from every week to every month. This is better, but it's still quite annoying and something that power users might have to do multiple times every month. You might not realize how many apps will bug you about these permissions until this feature rolls out. When it does, assuming it isn't altered before release, you may see one of two prompts:
[App] is requesting to bypass the system private window picker and directly access your screen and audio. This will allow [app name] to record your screen and system audio, including personal or sensitive information that may be visible or audible.
[App] can access this computer‚Äôs screen and audio. Do you want to continue to allow access? This application may be able to collect information from any open applications on your desktop while the app is running.
This change will apply to any app that can access your screen's contents, and that covers a lot of apps. For starters, you might be surprised to learn that any app with a color picker that can see your desktop or windows will need monthly permission to do so in macOS Sequoia. The same goes for screen recording and sharing apps, like OBS, Google Meet, Zoom, Teams, and more. Screenshot tools are subject to the monthly permission, too, so users of CleanShotX and similar apps will need to live with the prompts. Since this requirement is on a per-app basis, you'll have to do it for each app, 12 times per year.
It's shocking that there isn't an option to permanently allow screen sharing permission for specific apps in macOS Sequoia. If I know the app, trust the app, and need to share my screen regularly, why won't Apple let me do so without the hassle?
It's not the first change to hurt power users Multiple years later, the System Settings app is still poorly optimized for macOS
For me, this might be the change that makes me think twice about using macOS full-time. However, it's far from the only recent change to alter the workflows of power users for the worse. On a much smaller scale, I think the addition of the Control Center to the macOS menu bar represents a step backward. The entire purpose of the menu bar is to show information at a glance and house quick toggles and modules.
By putting some of these options behind the Control Center, Apple is just adding clicks to the process. People in the know can change this, thankfully, and move modules directly to the menu bar. But it's still a user-interface change that makes macOS more like iOS and needlessly dilutes the Mac's identity.
Related 4 features I wish Apple would steal from Windows Apple granted my wish with window snapping, but I want more
2 The worst offense is clearly the System Preferences overhaul a few years back that created System Settings . That's the new app for macOS settings, and it has the same downsides as the Control Center. It mimics iOS and iPadOS in ways that simply harm the macOS user experience. In the sidebar, the Displays page is the 15th option from the top, and the Keyboard page is the 27th option from the top. They're pushed lower so that pages like Notifications , Screen Time , and Focus are higher.
This matches iOS and iPadOS, but doesn't really make sense for the Mac. Changing your keyboard, mouse, and display settings is a frequent necessity for power users, and it's harder to do in recent versions of macOS.
How Apple can fix macOS for power users Choice! That's all it takes to keep advanced macOS experts happy
There's an easy solution to the permissions problem in macOS Sequoia. All Apple needs to do is give power users a way to permanently disable them, even if it's difficult. This may be something Apple adds before macOS Sequoia launches, because there's already a Persistent Content Capture value on the Apple Developer website. I'd be extremely disappointed if the company didn't give power users a choice beyond the monthly permission dialog boxes.
In general, it feels like iOS and iPadOS are gaining user choice ‚Äî especially in the EU ‚Äî while macOS users are losing it. That's unacceptable for me, and when these changes start to impact my workflow, I start to seriously wonder whether it's worth putting up with macOS. If they continue, I might be forced to give Windows another look despite being a longtime macOS enthusiast.
Related 15 settings you didn't know you should change on your Mac Revealing lesser-known macOS settings for power users

title: Copa Am√©rica 2024: La Vinotinto received 2-1 over Ecuador of their debut match
text:
The assembly occurred at Levi‚Äôs Stadium, California | Photograph: EFE La Vinotinto confronted Ecuador this Saturday, June 22, within the debut of each groups within the Copa Am√©rica 2024. The match occurred at Levi‚Äôs Stadium, in California, in the USA.
Venezuela, beneath the administration of Argentine Fernando ‚ÄúBocha‚Äù Batista, is fourth within the 2026 World Cup qualification and solely misplaced certainly one of six official matches. They beat Paraguay and Chile and tied in opposition to Brazil.
EFE/EPA/JOHN G. BANGLO La Vinotinto arrives with confidence and wind in its favor. In a bunch with Mexico, stuffed with doubts, and Jamaica, she has the ambition of reaching the quarterfinals.
For its half, Ecuador arrives at this Copa Am√©rica with the weapons which have marked it within the final 15 years, bodily power and energy, but in addition with pause and method.
Venezuela has handed the primary section of the Copa Am√©rica 4 occasions: 2007, 2011, 2016 and 2019; 2011 being the very best efficiency in its historical past, because it reached the semifinals.
Photograph: EFE/EPA/JOHN G. MABANGLO First time The match started with Ecuador dominating the ball and a reasonably bodily sport on the a part of Venezuela, with a number of aggressive tackles from the protection. This resulted in a number of free throws for Ecuador that didn‚Äôt compromise the Vinotinto purpose. Though Venezuela had an excellent retreat, along with the defensive motion of Osorio and C√°sseres, it lacked depth to advance within the Ecuadorian subject.
In the direction of the 18th minute, the primary shot on the Venezuelan purpose occurred by P√°ez, which was blocked by Romo. Nonetheless, in a second play, Enner Valencia kicked ‚ÄúEl Brujo Mart√≠nez‚Äù within the face, leaving him mendacity on the ground. This assault initially earned the Ecuadorian striker a yellow card, however a assessment of the play within the VAR decided the severity of the assault, so Valencia was despatched off with a direct pink card within the twenty second minute.
Now with 10 from Ecuador on the court docket, Vinotinto assumed a extra offensive position with a few forays by Salom√≥n Rond√≥n on purpose, with photographs by Osorio and Mach√≠s that have been repelled by the goalkeeper. Within the twenty ninth minute, the referee cautioned Sarmiento for a violent deal with on Yangel Herrera with a yellow card. Later, Mach√≠s additionally acquired the primary yellow for Venezuela within the thirtieth minute for a foul.
Within the thirty fourth minute, defender Kevin Rodr√≠guez got here on to interchange Yeboah, to readjust the Ecuadorian lineup, which turned extra defensive. Within the thirty ninth minute, a nasty clearance by Osorio after a free kick by P√°ez was taken benefit of by Sarmiento to attain the primary purpose for Ecuador. Venezuela tried to get better with a number of assaults in rival territory, however apart from a few photographs at Herrera‚Äôs purpose, they didn‚Äôt have sufficient drive to realize the tie.
Do your factor, Jeremy üòâ pic.twitter.com/5bBiUJYJvr
‚Äî CONMEBOL Copa Am√©rica‚Ñ¢Ô∏è (@CopaAmerica) June 22, 2024
As an alternative, C√°sseres acquired a yellow card for violently flattening Kevin Rodr√≠guez throughout an Ecuadorian counterattack. Thus, the primary half ended with a bonus for an Ecuador that, regardless of the numerical drawback and the Venezuelan assaults, knew methods to exploit the alternatives to reverse its scenario in opposition to a motivated, however missing, Venezuela.
Second time
Photograph: EFE/EPA/JOHN G. MABANGLO Venezuela started the second half with a few modifications to its gamers who have been cautioned within the first half. Jhonder C√°diz entered for Mach√≠s and Eduard Bello for C√°sseres. In the meantime, a grown Ecuador regardless of its minority on the sphere managed the match occasions, turning into a wall that was tough for the Venezuelans to cross. Sarmiento, with a purpose and a card, retired within the 62nd minute, changed by Carlos Gruezo.
‚ÄúBocha‚Äù Batista‚Äôs determination to place C√°diz and Bello in was probably the most profitable of the match. They confirmed it within the 58th minute, when a throw-in from Bello geared toward C√°diz who, pivoting round two defenders, shot at Dom√≠nguez‚Äôs purpose, scoring his first purpose with the Venezuelan group. Venezuela continued to press, and within the 74th minute it was Bello‚Äôs flip to attain the second purpose, ending off a header from Rond√≥n that had been cleared by the goalkeeper.
Alan Miranda and Jordy Caicedo entered within the 79th minute for P√°ez and Franco Palma to attempt to regain management of the sport. La Vinotinto did the identical within the 83rd minute with Jefferson Savarino and Eric Ram√≠rez additionally changing Soteldo and Salo Rond√≥n, to keep up dominance and strain. For additional time, Tom√°s Rinc√≥n entered for Herrera to strengthen the midfield, after a few harmful conditions generated by C√°diz that would have been a 3rd purpose.
Thus, Venezuela provides its first three factors inside group B. Though it‚Äôs beginning on an excellent foot within the match, it nonetheless has to face Mexico on June 26, along with the match in opposition to Jamaica (June 30) to outline its classification.

author: az-online.de
title: Bundessieg "bunt statt blau": Sch√ºlerin aus Schleswig-Holstein gewinnt DAK-Wettbewerb gegen das Rauschtrinken
text:
Bundessieg "bunt statt blau": Sch√ºlerin aus Schleswig-Holstein gewinnt DAK-Wettbewerb gegen das Rauschtrinken
Hamburg (ots) - Die Bundessiegerin 2025 von "bunt statt blau - Kunst gegen Komasaufen" kommt aus Schleswig-Holstein: Vivien Manzke aus B√∂neb√ºttel gewinnt den bundesweiten DAK-Plakatwettbewerb vor Leonie Scholl (Baden-W√ºrttemberg) und Eva Arkenbosch (Hessen). Mehr als 7.000 Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler hatten sich in diesem Jahr an der Pr√§ventionskampagne der DAK-Gesundheit zum Thema Alkoholmissbrauch beteiligt.
Bereits zum 16. Mal suchte die Kasse die besten Plakate gegen das Rauschtrinken. Bundesschirmherr ist der neue Beauftragte der Bundesregierung f√ºr Sucht- und Drogenfragen Prof. Dr. Hendrik Streeck. Seit dem Start von "bunt statt blau" 2010 haben insgesamt rund 143.000 Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler zwischen zw√∂lf und 17 Jahren kreative Plakate gegen Alkoholexzesse gestaltet. "Die Bundessiegerin macht mit ihrem Plakat Emotionen sichtbar: Junge Menschen, die sich durch Alkoholkonsum wie in Ketten gelegt f√ºhlen und darunter leiden, stehen im Kontrast zu einem jungen M√§dchen, das sich davon befreit hat. Es gelingt der jungen K√ºnstlerin damit sehr gut zu veranschaulichen, wie positiv sich der Verzicht auf Alkoholkonsum auswirkt", lobt Andreas Storm, Vorstandschef der DAK-Gesundheit das Plakat der Bundessiegerin Vivien Manzke. Gemeinsam mit dem Beauftragten der Bundesregierung f√ºr Sucht- und Drogenfragen Prof. Dr. Hendrik Streeck und Prof. Reiner Hanewinkel, Leiter des Instituts f√ºr Therapie- und Gesundheitsforschung (IFT-Nord), w√§hlte Storm in der Bundesjury die ersten Pl√§tze aus.
"Jede und jeder von ihnen h√§tte einen Preis verdient. Die Entscheidung fiel uns nicht leicht. Mein Gl√ºckwunsch an alle, die ausgezeichnet wurden", sagt der Beauftragte der Bundesregierung f√ºr Sucht- und Drogenfragen Prof. Dr. Hendrik Streeck. "Als Schirmherr unterst√ºtze ich diese Kampagne ausgesprochen gern. Wir brauchen viel mehr Aufkl√§rung in den Schulen und nat√ºrlich auch zu Hause ein gr√∂√üeres Bewusstsein, wie gef√§hrlich Alkohol f√ºr Kinder und Jugendliche sein kann. Da ist noch viel zu tun. Auch als Politik k√∂nnen wir unseren Beitrag leisten. Es ist richtig, dass wir endlich offen dar√ºber sprechen, ob Regelungen wie das 'begleitete Trinken' noch zeitgem√§√ü sind. Bier und Wein werden schlie√ülich nicht ges√ºnder, nur weil Erwachsene danebensitzen."
Mit dem Bundessieg kann sich Vivien Manzke √ºber den Hauptpreis von 500 Euro freuen. "Ich m√∂chte mit meinem Bild zeigen, dass es einen Ausweg aus der Alkoholsucht gibt und dass die Hoffnung, insbesondere bei Jugendlichen, nicht stirbt, gesund zu werden und ein normales Leben zu f√ºhren", beschreibt die 15-J√§hrige ihre Plakatidee. "Mein Bild zeigt, wie sich ein M√§dchen von den Ketten des Alkohols befreit. Es zeigt das Gl√ºcklichsein ohne den Alkohol, aber auch die Traurigkeit der Jugendlichen, die immer noch an Alkohol gekettet sind. Im Ganzen m√∂chte ich mit meinem Werk Hoffnung zum Ausweg aus dem Alkohol f√ºr Jugendliche geben und auch klarmachen, dass niemand f√ºr immer in dieser H√∂lle stecken muss." Baden-W√ºrttemberg gewinnt in diesem Jahr Silber: Die 18-j√§hrige Leonie Scholl aus Pforzheim holt sich Platz zwei. Bronze geht nach Hessen: Hier √ºberzeugte die 18-j√§hrige Eva Arkenbosch aus Hofheim am Taunus die Bundesjury. Der Sonderpreis in der Kategorie "Junge Talente" geht an Marlene Damm, 13 Jahre, aus Bremen. Beim Sonderpreis "Social Media" liegt Nordrhein-Westfalen vorne: Hier √ºberzeugten Greta-Luise Schulte, Neele Radin und Leonie Steuerwald aus Lippstadt mit einem Videobeitrag auf YouTube.
"bunt statt blau - Kunst gegen Komasaufen": Unter diesem Motto suchte die DAK-Gesundheit 2025 bereits im 16. Jahr die besten Plakatideen von Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºlern zwischen zw√∂lf und 17 Jahren zum Thema Rauschtrinken. Auch in diesem Jahr wurden zun√§chst in den Bundesl√§ndern Landessiegerinnen und Landessieger gek√ºrt. Aus diesen Bildern w√§hlte die Bundesjury die besten Plakate aus.
Zahlen des Statistischen Bundesamtes zeigen, dass die Zahl jugendlicher Rauschtrinkerinnen und Rauschtrinker weiter r√ºckl√§ufig ist. So mussten 2023 9.263 Jugendliche mit einem Rausch in Kliniken behandelt werden. Das war bundesweit ein R√ºckgang um 19 Prozent im Vergleich zum Vorjahr. 2022 waren es noch 11.472 Jugendliche gewesen. Dabei sanken die Zahlen in allen Altersgruppen (zehn bis unter 20 Jahre). Am st√§rksten nahm die Zahl der Rauschtrinkenden mit minus 21 Prozent bei den 15- bis 19-j√§hrigen Jungen ab. Bei den M√§dchen in dieser Altersgruppe sank die Anzahl der Rauschtrinkerinnen lediglich um 14 Prozent. Zum Vergleich: Der Ausl√∂ser zum Start von "bunt statt blau" im Jahr 2010 waren mehr als 25.000 Krankenhausbehandlungen von Minderj√§hrigen mit einer Alkoholvergiftung.
Der Beauftragte der Bundesregierung f√ºr Sucht- und Drogenfragen Prof. Dr. Hendrik Streeck sagt ganz klar: "Jeder junge Mensch, der mit einer Alkoholvergiftung in einer Klinik landet, ist einer zu viel. Darum brauchen wir weiterhin gute, passgenaue und vor allem fr√ºhzeitige Aufkl√§rung in Kindertageseinrichtungen, Schulen, Sport- und Freizeitangeboten wie Vereinen und anderen Jugendorten. Kinder und Jugendliche sollen gar nicht zu Alkohol oder anderen Drogen greifen."
"Es ist ein gutes Signal, dass die Zahl der Klinikeinweisungen im Bereich Alkoholmissbrauch abnimmt", sagt Andreas Storm. "Die Entwicklung der Zahlen seit dem Start der Kampagne im Jahr 2010 macht deutlich, wie kraftvoll Pr√§ventionsinitiativen wie 'bunt statt blau' wirken k√∂nnen. Angesichts tausender Jugendlicher, die noch immer j√§hrlich mit einem Vollrausch in der Klinik behandelt werden m√ºssen, gilt es jedoch, dranzubleiben. Es ist wichtig, junge Menschen f√ºr die negativen Folgen von Alkoholkonsum zu sensibilisieren, aber ohne erhobenen Zeigefinger." Storm weiter: "'Bunt statt blau' ermutigt Sch√ºlerinnen und Sch√ºler dazu, ihren Umgang mit Alkohol zu hinterfragen. Der Schl√ºssel zum Erfolg ist eine Kommunikation auf Augenh√∂he. Das macht 'bunt statt blau' so besonders."
Die Pr√§ventionskampagne "bunt statt blau" ist eingebunden in die "Aktion Glasklar" des IFT-Nord, mit der die DAK-Gesundheit auch Lehrkr√§fte und Eltern √ºber das Thema Alkohol aufkl√§rt. Mit passgenauen Unterrichtsmaterialien wird das Thema Alkoholmissbrauch von Lehrerinnen und Lehrern aufgegriffen, bevor die Gestaltung der Plakate und Beitr√§ge beginnt.

author: DOUG SMITH Los Angeles Times
title: $750 a month, no questions asked, improved the lives of homeless people
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî If 100 homeless people were given $750 per month for a year, no questions asked, what would they spend it on? That question was at the core of a controlled study conducted by a San Francisco-based nonprofit and the USC Suzanne Dworak-Peck School of Social Work. The results were so promising that the researchers decided to publish results after only six months. The answer: food, 36.6%; housing, 19.5%; transportation, 12.7%; clothing, 11.5%; and health care, 6.2%, leaving only 13.6% uncategorized. Those who got the stipend were less likely to be unsheltered after six months and able to meet more of their basic needs than a control group that got no money, and half as likely as the control group to have an episode of being unsheltered. ‚ÄúI felt there was enough interest and the initial findings were compelling enough that it was important to get those results out,‚Äù said Benjamin Henwood, director of the Center for Homelessness, Housing and Health Equity Research at the Dworak-Peck School, who led the study. People are also reading‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúIt may not be earth-shattering that providing money is going to help meet basic needs, but I do think it dispels this myth that people will use money for illicit purposes,‚Äù Henwood said. ‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt finding that in the study.‚Äù About 2% of the total went to alcohol, cigarettes and drug expenses ‚Äî the largest portion of which was cigarettes, Henwood said. The participants submit monthly reports on their spending and are surveyed in more detail quarterly. A follow-up report will be published after participants have received the funds for a full year. But Henwood said the main findings were robust enough that they were unlikely to change. The study arose from Miracle Messages, a San Francisco-based nonprofit that sends volunteers to the streets and shelters to befriend homeless people and try to make connections with the loved ones who lost contact with them. Next founder and chief executive Kevin F. Adler started Miracle Friends, matching homeless people to volunteer phone buddies for weekly calls. That evolved into Miracle Money when volunteers began asking Adler whether it was OK to give their buddies a few dollars. ‚ÄúYou asked me to be a friend to this person, but they don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre going to eat tonight,‚Äù Adler said they would tell him. Adler didn‚Äôt think the volunteers should hand out their own money. But the idea of cash support appealed to him. After a pilot showed promise, Adler got a grant to expand to Los Angeles. He hired two recruiters to canvass homeless shelters. They enlisted more than 200 clients who met the criteria of being at least 18 years old and homeless and expressed interest in having a phone buddy. Rather than just give money away, Adler hoped to document its effect. He teamed up with Henwood, who devised the controlled study. The participants were divided randomly into two groups. One group of 103 received stipends. The others were told they were on a waiting list. After six months, only 12% of those who received funds reported being unsheltered at any time in the prior month, a dramatic decrease from 30% at the outset. Those on the waiting list also reported fewer unsheltered episodes, but by a much smaller margin, from 28% to 23%. The cash recipients also said they were better able to meet their basic needs. On a scale of 1 (completely) to 5 (not at all), they dropped from about 3.75 on average to just over 3.25. The control group did not budge from 3.75. Among those receiving the funds, some found permanent housing, even though the money fell far below average rents in the area, Henwood said. ‚ÄúIt seems like it‚Äôs opening up possibilities in different ways,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey might have a friend or relative that may not be willing to support them completely, but if they have something to contribute that opens up a room.‚Äù In other cases, the money created opportunities, even for people who remained unsheltered. ‚ÄúI spent a lot of the money on food on the go,‚Äù one participant told the researchers. ‚ÄúSimple, cheap things like bean and cheese burritos. I eat on the run while I bike/work for DoorDash. I also bought a membership to REI, so I could get my bike fixed for free.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a single path forward,‚Äù Henwood said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a lot of resourcefulness and creativity.‚Äù 20 facts about homelessness in the US 20 facts about homelessness in the US According to HUD, there were 582,462 people experiencing homelessness in the U.S. in January 2022 The U.S. has seen a 0.3% increase in homelessness since 2020 Conversely, the U.S. has seen an 8.6% decrease in homelessness since 2010 Experts from HUD believe that resources from the American Rescue Plan directed toward homelessness assistance lessened the impact of COVID-19 on homelessness The end of the federal eviction moratorium in August 2021 made millions of Americans' housing situations more precarious during the long tail of the COVID-19 pandemic As of August 2022, one year after the federal eviction moratorium was lifted, nearly 12% of Americans experienced a rent increase of $250 or more per month The marked increase in rental prices during COVID-19 likely contributed to the recent rise in homelessness HUD's Emergency Rental Assistance program received more than 12 million applications for assistance between August 2021 and January 2022 A greater proportion of people experiencing homelessness were unsheltered in 2022 compared to 2020 40% of all people experiencing homelessness in the U.S. during 2022 were unsheltered Chronic homelessness has increased 15.5% since 2020 Veteran homelessness has decreased by 11% since 2020 and more than 50% since 2010 Family and youth homelessness have both decreased since 2020 50,767 families with children experienced homelessness in 2022 Since 2020, unaccompanied youth homelessness has decreased by 12% 6,398 parenting youth taking care of 7,898 children experienced homelessness in 2022, down 13% since 2020 In 2022, 37% of people experiencing homelessness identified as Black, while only 12% of the overall U.S. population identifies as Black From 2020 to 2022, the number of people who identified as Hispanic or Latino who experienced homelessness rose by 8% The number of people who identify as Hispanic and experienced unsheltered homelessness in 2022 rose 16% since 2020

center for homelessness, housing and health equity research

title: Alerta meteorol√≥gica nivel naranja por tormentas severas y granizo: a qu√© hora empiezan y d√≥nde | La 100
text: El [Servicio Meteorol√≥gico Nacional (SMN)](https://la100.cienradios.com/clima/verano-la-contundente-advertencia-del-servicio-meteorologico-nacional/) emiti√≥ una alerta meteorol√≥gica nivel naranja por tormentas severas para el √∫ltimo d√≠a h√°bil de 2023 en tres provincias del norte argentino. El alarmante pron√≥stico para el primer trimestre de 2024: cu√°ndo llega la fuerte ola de calor Alerta meteorol√≥gica nivel naranja en el norte ‚ÄúEl √°rea ser√° afectada por tormentas, algunas localmente fuertes. Las mismas pueden estar acompa√±adas por r√°fagas intensas, importante actividad el√©ctrica, ocasional ca√≠da de granizo y abundante ca√≠da de agua en cortos per√≠odos de tiempo‚Äù, anticip√≥ el SMN para Tucum√°n, Salta y Jujuy. En tal sentido, la entidad clim√°tiva previ√≥ valores de precipitaci√≥n acumulada entre 50 y 70 mm, pudiendo ser superados en forma puntual por la noche de este viernes 29 de diciembre. Tucum√°n Burruyac√∫ - Capital - Cruz Alta - Famaill√° - Graneros - La Cocha - Leales - Simoca - Trancas - Yerba Buena - Zonas bajas de Chicligasta - Zonas bajas de Juan Bautista Alberdi - Zonas bajas de Lules - Zonas bajas de Monteros - Zonas bajas de R√≠o Chico - Zonas bajas de Taf√≠ Viejo. Una fuerte tormenta se sinti√≥ en Buenos Aires y provoc√≥ graves destrozos en La Pampa por el granizo Zona monta√±osa de Chicligasta - Zona monta√±osa de Juan Bautista Alberdi - Zona monta√±osa de Lules - Zona monta√±osa de Monteros - Zona monta√±osa de R√≠o Chico - Zona monta√±osa de Taf√≠ Viejo - Zona monta√±osa de Taf√≠ del Valle - Zona monta√±osa de Andalgal√° - Zona monta√±osa de Santa Mar√≠a. Salta Capital - Cerrillos - Guachipas - La Vi√±a - Zona baja de Chicoana - Zona baja de La Caldera - Zona baja de Rosario de Lerma - Zona monta√±osa de Cafayate - Anta - General G√ºemes - La Candelaria - Met√°n - Rosario de la Frontera - Rivadavia - Pre Puna de Iruya - Pre Puna de Or√°n - Pre Puna de Santa Victoria. Jujuy El Carmen - Ledesma - Palpal√° - San Antonio - San Pedro - Santa B√°rbara - Valle Grande - Zona baja de Doctor Manuel Belgrano - Zona baja de Tilcara.
